column10: machine learning approaches promise to provide more accurate and geographically wide-ranging isoscapes over time. Using strontium isotope analysis for provenancing is most successful when combined with other isotopes and/or trace elements as part of a likelihood approach. Strontium isoscapes that are both appropriate and sufficiently high resolution to answer specific research questions do not exist for most parts of the world. Researchers intending to incorporate strontium analysis into their research designs should expect to conduct primary sampling and analysis to create appropriate isoscapes or refine existing ones

column4: Jonathan"	"Machine Learning Based Assembly of Fragments of Ancient Papyrus"	"Acm Journal on Computing and Cultural Heritage"	"The task of assembling fragments in a puzzle-like manner into a composite picture plays a significant role in the field of archaeology as it supports researchers in their attempt to reconstruct historic artifacts. In this article
column5: we propose a method for matching and assembling pairs of ancient papyrus fragments containing mostly unknown scriptures. Papyrus paper is manufactured from papyrus plants and therefore portrays typical thread patterns resulting from the plant's stems. The proposed algorithm is founded on the hypothesis that these thread patterns contain unique local attributes such that nearby fragments show similar patterns reflecting the continuations of the threads. We posit that these patterns can be exploited using image processing and machine learning techniques to identify matching fragments. The algorithm and system which we present support the quick and automated classification of matching pairs of papyrus fragments as well as the geometric alignment of the pairs against each other. The algorithm consists of a series of steps and is based on deep-learning and machine learning methods. The first step is to deconstruct the problem of matching fragments into a smaller problem of finding thread continuation matches in local edge areas (squares) between pairs of fragments. This phase is solved using a convolutional neural network ingesting raw images of the edge areas and producing local matching scores. The result of this stage yields very high recall but low precision. Thus
column6: we utilize these scores in order to conclude about the matching of entire fragments pairs by establishing an elaborate voting mechanism. We enhance this voting with geometric alignment techniques from which we extract additional spatial information. Eventually
column7: we feed all the data collected from these steps into a Random Forest classifier in order to produce a higher order classifier capable of predicting whether a pair of fragments is a match. Our algorithm was trained on a batch of fragments which was excavated from the Dead Sea caves and is dated circa the 1st century BCE. The algorithm shows excellent results on a validation set which is of a similar origin and conditions. We then tried to run the algorithm against a real-life set of fragments for which we have no prior knowledge or labeling of matches. This test batch is considered extremely challenging due to its poor condition and the small size of its fragments. Evidently
column8: numerous researchers have tried seeking matches within this batch with very little success. Our algorithm performance on this batch was sub-optimal
column9: returning a relatively large ratio of false positives. However
column10: the algorithm was quite useful by eliminating 98% of the possiblematches thus reducing the amount of work needed formanual inspection. Indeed
column11: experts that reviewed the results have identified some positive matches as potentially true and referred them for further investigation."	"Abitbol et al. - 2021 - Machine Learning Based Assembly of Fragments of An.txt"

column2: JR"	"Peak Document and the Future of History"	"AMERICAN HISTORICAL REVIEW"	"Among the ongoing revolutions in historical research is the flood of new information about the past that comes not from written documents but from the natural sciences and archaeology. column3: T"	"Excavating AI: the politics of images in machine learning training sets"	"AI & SOCIETY"	"By looking at the politics of classification within machine learning systems

column9: emotions
column10: ability
column11: sexuality
column12: and personality? Finally
column13: we turn to the purposes that computer vision is meant to serve in our society-the judgments

column17: cataloguing the principles and values by which taxonomies are constructed

column7: JH"	"A Boat Is a Boat Is a Boat horizontal ellipsis Unless It Is a Horse - Rethinking the Role of Typology"	"OPEN ARCHAEOLOGY"	"Today
column8: it is widely accepted that typology is a biased and inconsistent attempt to classify archaeological material based on the similarity of a predefined set of features. In this respect
column9: machine learning (ML) works similar to typology. ML approaches are often deployed because it is thought that they reduce biases. However

column13: it was noticed that the algorithm struggles with classifying certain motifs correctly. This contribution discusses the consistency in applying biases by ML in contrast to the inconsistency of human classification. It is argued that it is necessary to bring machines and humans into a meaningful dialogue attempting to understand why apparent \misclassifications \\" happen. This is important to inform us about the classification output

column3: JB"	"Multiple approaches to predicting flake mass"	"JOURNAL OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL SCIENCE-REPORTS"	"Predicting original flake mass is a major goal of lithic analysis. Predicting original flake mass allows for researchers to make estimations of remaining mass
column5: and other features. All these measures relate to the organization of lithic technology by past societies. The present work tests three different models to predict log of flake mass: multiple linear regression
column6: random forest regression
column7: and artificial neural networks (ANN). Estimations of flake mass were performed using the remaining features of flakes from an experimental assemblage. This assemblage was obtained by the expansion of a previous dataset through the inclusion of bigger flakes
column8: allowing the analysis to account for the effects of sample size and value distribution. Correlation results show a large/strong relation between predictions and real outcome (r(2) = 0.78 in the best case). Comparison of the models affords insights into variable importance for predicting flake mass. Results show that (for the present dataset) multiple linear regression still stands as the best method for predicting log of flake weight. Additionally
column9: transformation of predicted values from the multiple linear regression and true values to the linear scale reinforces the linear correlation above the 0.8 threshold."	"Bustos-Pérez et Preysler - 2022 - Multiple approaches to predicting flake mass.txt"

column4: M"	"Multiclass Land Cover Mapping from Historical Orthophotos Using Domain Adaptation and Spatio-Temporal Transfer Learning"	"REMOTE SENSING"	"Historical land cover (LC) maps are an essential instrument for studying long-term spatio-temporal changes of the landscape. However
column5: manual labelling on low-quality monochromatic historical orthophotos for semantic segmentation (pixel-level classification) is particularly challenging and time consuming. Therefore
column6: this paper proposes a methodology for the automated extraction of very-high-resolution (VHR) multi-class LC maps from historical orthophotos under the absence of target-specific ground truth annotations. The methodology builds on recent evolutions in deep learning
column7: leveraging domain adaptation and transfer learning. First
column8: an unpaired image-to-image (I2I) translation between a source domain (recent RGB image of high quality
column9: annotations available) and the target domain (historical monochromatic image of low quality
column10: no annotations available) is learned using a conditional generative adversarial network (GAN). Second
column11: a state-of-the-art fully convolutional network (FCN) for semantic segmentation is pre-trained on a large annotated RGB earth observation (EO) dataset that is converted to the target domain using the I2I function. Third
column12: the FCN is fine-tuned using self-annotated data on a recent RGB orthophoto of the study area under consideration
column13: after conversion using again the I2I function. The methodology is tested on a new custom dataset: the 'Sagalassos historical land cover dataset'
column14: which consists of three historical monochromatic orthophotos (1971
column16: 1992) and one recent RGB orthophoto (2015) of VHR (0.3-0.84 m GSD) all capturing the same greater area around Sagalassos archaeological site (Turkey)
column17: and corresponding manually created annotations (2.7 km(2) per orthophoto) distinguishing 14 different LC classes. Furthermore
column18: a comprehensive overview of open-source annotated EO datasets for multiclass semantic segmentation is provided
column19: based on which an appropriate pretraining dataset can be selected. Results indicate that the proposed methodology is effective
column20: increasing the mean intersection over union by 27.2% when using domain adaptation
column21: and by 13.0% when using domain pretraining
column22: and that transferring weights from a model pretrained on a dataset closer to the target domain is preferred."	"van den Broeck et al. - 2022 - Multiclass Land Cover Mapping from Historical Orth.txt"

column9: D"	"A hybrid 3D object auto-completion approach with self-supervised data augmentation for fragments of archaeological objects"	"JOURNAL OF CULTURAL HERITAGE"	"It is a common case that archaeological finds are frequently found in fragments and cannot always be reassembled in their entirety. Additionally
column10: the completion of their shape and volume is sometimes costly and occasionally requires a lot of manual work
column11: in particular for exhibition purposes. As a first step
column12: improving the geometry of the fragments could potentially help the archaeological conservators in the assembling process. In this direction
column13: in this paper we propose an end-to-end hybrid approach (i.e. point clouds to benefit from the limited complexity and creating results in mesh benefiting from their visualization capabilities) for the digital auto-completion of fragmented archaeological artifacts with missing parts in combination with a novel self-supervised data augmentation scheme in order to address a significant limitation in the archaeological domain (i.e. limited available observations and absence of the complete object). Our approach uses only 5 fragments of a partly preserved archaeological object for training. As a first step
column14: an object (i.e artifact fragment) in mesh representation is converted to point cloud
column15: from which more fragments of the incomplete original object are artificially generated
column16: with the help of 3D surfaces
column17: to augment the dataset. This dataset is then passed in a GAN-based Cascaded refinement network for generating a complete output
column18: which is
column19: finally
column20: converted back to a mesh. Our experiments showed that the proposed hybrid approach
column21: can be successfully used to complete and restore the geometry of a partly preserved archaeological object without having ever seen the complete form of it. However
column22: due to the complexity of the fragments
column23: such methods in most cases cannot generate their fine decorative and surface details. (c) 2022 Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights reserved."	"Stasinakis et al. - 2022 - A hybrid 3D object auto-completion approach with s.txt"

column3: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE AND OTHER AMENITIES: PLAYING WITH COLORS ON PANCHROMATIC AERIAL PHOTOGRAPHS"	"GEOMEDIA"	"Historical photographs
column4: whether taken from the air or from the ground
column5: are usually syno-nyms of grayscale or sepia prints. From the very beginning of photography
column6: during the first half of 19th century
column7: people were amazed by this new media that could record all aspects of a scene with great detail. Soon though
column8: everybody started wondering why would such an impressive innovation fail to record colors? A process of trials and errors then started (induding the most successful and pioneer one
column9: involving the use of potato starch
column10: by Lu-miere brothers) aiming to add colors to photographs
column11: till the consolidation of new systems (camera and film) capable to collect photographs directly in color. In the past
column12: before and during this innovative approach
column13: native black and white photographs were painted in the effort to give them life. Today
column14: only few methods are available to convert a panchromatic image into a color one
column15: and they need a number of steps and further development to work properly. The paper tries to present different methods to colorize native black and white photographs
column16: based on available automatic or interactive Artificial Intelligence (Machine Learning or Deep Learning) algorithms
column17: on revised remote sensing procedures and on visual tricks
column18: aiming at exploring the possible improvement in readability and interpreta-tion of photographed contests in the usual analytic process of photo-interpretation. At the same time
column19: colorized historical photographs hold different appeal in the general public and have the potential to attract and involve non-experts in the archaeological/historical reconstruction phases."	"Cantoro - 2022 - POTATOES

column21: SQ"	"Cultural and demic co-diffusion of Tubo Empire on Tibetan Plateau"	"ISCIENCE"	"A high point of Tibetan Plateau (TP) civilization
column22: the expansive Tubo Empire (618–842 AD) wielded great in?uence across ancient western China. However
column23: whether the Tubo expansion was cultural or demic remains unclear due to sparse ancient DNA sampling. Here
column24: we reported ten ancient genomes at 0.017- to 0.867-fold coverages from the Dulan site with typical Tubo archaeological culture dating to 1308–1130 BP. Nine individuals from three different grave types have close relationship with previously reported ancient highlanders from the south-western Himalayas and modern core-Tibetan populations. A Dulan-related Tubo ancestry contributed overwhelmingly (95%–100%) to the formation of modern Tibetans. A genetic outlier with dominant Eurasian steppe-related ancestry sug-gesting a potential population movement into the Tubo-controlled regions from Central Asia. Together with archeological evidence from burial styles and cus-toms
column25: our study suggested the impact of the Tubo empire on the northeast edge of the TP involved both cultural and demic diffusion."	"Zhu et al. - 2022 - Cultural and demic co-diffusion of Tubo Empire on .txt"
